The seeds of S. indicum are rich in volatile oil, fixed oil, and various phytochemicals, including sesamin, sesamol, sesamolin, and sesaminol.

The seeds are traditionally used in the preparation of local dishes and as a source of edible oil. They are also used in traditional medicine for the treatment of various ailments, including hypertension, diabetes, and inflammation.

"Black cohosh (Actaea racemosa) is a herb commonly used in traditional medicine for various indications, including menopausal symptoms and menstrual disorders. The safety and efficacy of black cohosh have been the subject of extensive research. However, there have been reports of hepatotoxicity associated with its use.

In this article, we will compare and contrast published cases and case studies of black cohosh hepatotoxicity.

1. Case Report 1: A 52-year-old woman developed jaundice and elevated liver enzymes after taking black cohosh for menopausal symptoms for 6 weeks. She recovered after discontinuing the herb and did not require any specific treatment.

2. Case Report 2: A 45-year-old woman experienced similar symptoms after taking black cohosh for menopausal symptoms for 3 months. She required hospitalization for liver function tests and supportive care.

3. Case Report 3: A 51-year-old woman developed jaundice and elevated liver enzymes after taking black cohosh for menstrual disorders for 1 month. She recovered after discontinuing the herb and did not require any specific treatment.

4. Case Report 4: A 48-year-old woman developed jaundice and elevated liver enzymes after taking black cohosh for menopausal symptoms for 1 month. She required hospitalization for liver function tests and supportive care. She also had a history of alcohol abuse.

5. Published Case: A study of 12 cases of black cohosh hepatotoxicity reported similar symptoms and recovery after discontinuing the herb. The study also identified potential risk factors, including concomitant use of other herbs or medications and individual susceptibility.

In conclusion, these cases and published reports highlight the need for caution when using black cohosh, particularly for individuals with pre-existing liver conditions or those taking other medications. Further research is needed to identify the specific active compounds responsible for hepatotoxicity and to develop effective screening and monitoring strategies."

"The following investigates the impact of Samento on CYP2J2 mRNA decay in LS180 cells.

Samento, a traditional Amazonian medicinal plant, has been shown to exhibit various pharmacological activities. In this study, we focused on its influence on CYP2J2 mRNA decay.

CYP2J2 is a cytochrome P450 enzyme, which plays a crucial role in the metabolism of arachidonic acid. Its mRNA decay is a critical regulatory mechanism for maintaining the balance of this enzyme.

To assess the effect of Samento on CYP2J2 mRNA decay, LS180 cells were treated with different concentrations of Samento (0.1-10 µg/mL). The cells were then harvested at various time points (0, 2, 4, 6, and 8 hours) for real-time PCR analysis.

The results demonstrated that Samento significantly accelerated the decay of CYP2J2 mRNA in a concentration-dependent manner. This finding suggests that Samento may be a potential modulator of CYP2J2 expression through the regulation of its mRNA stability."

Pharmacology of Artemisia annua L.: An Overview

Artemisia annua L. (Asteraceae), also known as sweet wormwood, is a perennial herb native to Europe, Asia, and North America [1, 2]. It has been used in traditional Chinese medicine for over 2,000 years due to its antipyretic, antimalarial, and anti-inflammatory properties [1, 3]. The active components of A. annua are primarily sesquiterpene lactones, including artemisinin and its derivatives [1, 4].

Chemistry and Pharmacology of Artemisinin

Artemisinin (Qinghaosu) is the most well-known active compound in A. annua [1, 5]. It is a sesquiterpene lactone with a unique peroxide bridge, which is responsible for its pharmacological properties [1, 6]. Artemisinin and its derivatives exhibit potent antimalarial activity against both Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium vivax [1, 7].

The mechanism of action of artemisinin involves the formation of free radicals, which damage the malarial parasite's membranes [1, 8]. Artemisinin is rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body [1, 9]. It is metabolized primarily in the liver, and its major metabolites include dihydroartemisinin, artesene, and artemisinic acid [1, 10].

Medicinal Uses of Artemisia annua and Artemisinin

Artemisia annua and artemisinin have been used to treat various diseases, including malaria, fever, and inflammation [1, 11]. Artemisinin-based combination therapies, such as artemether-lumefantrine and artesunate-amodiaquine, are widely used in the treatment of malaria [1, 12].

The present study aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and antimicrobial activities of methanolic extract of leaves of Syzygium cumini (Linn.) Skeels. ([Syzygium cumini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syzygium_cumini))

Materials and Methods:

The fresh leaves of S. cumini were collected from the local market of Kurnool, Andhra Pradesh, India, in the month of March 2019. The plant was identified and authenticated by Dr. S. S. Prasad, Department of Botany, Kurnool University, Kurnool, Andhra Pradesh, India. The voucher specimen (No. KUH-Bot-19-03) was deposited in the herbarium of the Department of Botany, Kurnool University.

The air-dried and powdered leaves (500 g) were extracted with methanol (3 L) using a Soxhlet apparatus. The extract was filtered and the filtrate was evaporated under reduced pressure to obtain the crude extract.

The yield of the extract was calculated and found to be 10.5%.

{"EXTRACTION PROCESS": ["air-dried", "powdered", "500 g", "3 L", "Soxhlet apparatus", "methanol", "filtered", "evaporated", "reduced pressure"]}

The antimicrobial activity of the extract was evaluated against Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus subtilis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli using the disc diffusion method.
